chapter.title: Application Server
chapter.para: Two primary ways to run the application server

listitem.para: Standalone. Can be local or remote
Embedded within IDE. Shares same JVM.
Deployed applications log to an API (e.g., commons-logging, slf4j)
API bound to server logger mechanism (e.g., log4j)

figure.title: Adjust Verbosity for Application
figure.programlisting: # standalone/configuration/standalone.xml <logger category="info.ejava"> <level name="DEBUG"/> </logger> <root-logger> <level name="INFO"/> <handlers> <handler name="CONSOLE"/> <handler name="FILE"/> </handlers> </root-logger>

listitem.para: root-logger sets default versbosity to INFO
additional logger sets verbosity for info.ejava.* to DEBUG

figure.title: Application Code

listitem.para: EJB class used to create logger named after the class' fully qualified name
@PostConstruct logging at INFO level
business method logging at DEBUG level
Console configured (by default) to only output INFO and above

figure.title: Server log/server.log Output
figure.programlisting:
$ tail -n 999 -f standalone/log/server.log
2014-10-01 01:17:01,990 INFO [info.ejava.examples.ejb.basic.ejb.GreeterEJB] (EJB default - 1) *** GreeterEJB *** 2014-10-01 01:17:02,009 DEBUG [info.ejava.examples.ejb.basic.ejb.GreeterEJB] (EJB default - 1) sayHello(cat inhat)

listitem.para: server.log will print all verbosity levels
Runs as separate process
Started/stopped by shell commands
Decoupled from IDE
Use start script (standalone.sh or standalone.bat)

listitem.para: Server can be started at the command line
Add -c profile-name.xml to run alternate profile in standalone/configuration
Server can be safely shutdown using the command line shell or Control-C
All server actions can be scripted with command-line interface
